text: ‘T.. patterns of Gothie fenestration were ordered according

text: work of the European functionalists.
label: Paragraph

text: This. second principle of contemporary style in architecture
label: Paragraph

text: has to do with regularity, The supports in skeleton construction
label: Paragraph

text: are normally and typically spaced at equal distances in order

text: that strains may be equalized. (Pages 117 and 149.) Thus most
label: Paragraph

text: buildings have an underlying regular rhythm which is clearly
label: Paragraph

text: seett before the outside surfaces are applied. Moreover, eco-
label: Paragraph

text: nomic considerations favor the use of standardized parts
label: Paragraph

text: throughout. Good modern architecture expresses in its design
label: Paragraph

text: this characteristic orderliness of structure and this similarity of
label: Paragraph

text: parts by an esthetic ordering which emphasizes the underlying
label: Paragraph

text: regularity. Bad modern design contradicts this regularity. Regu-
label: Paragraph

text: Jarity is, however, relative and not absolute in architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The varied purposes which most buildings serve cannot be
label: Paragraph

text: completely regularized. A loft building in a city may be, and
label: Paragraph

text: often is, regular throughout except for the entrances and the
label: Paragraph

text: elevators. (Page 162.) The many purposes which each floor
label: Paragraph

text: serves are so neatly alike that the same plan and elevation may
label: Paragraph

text: be used throughout. Few buildings, however, are so simple, In
label: Paragraph

text: most cases, within a structure as regular as possible and using
label: Paragraph

text: similar parts the architect must provide for many varying func-
label: Paragraph

text: tions related in various different ways to one another. In a hotel,
label: Paragraph

text: for example, although the suites considered as units repeat them-
label: Paragraph

text: selves, the lobbies, dining rooms and kitchens serve the whole

text: building and are on an entirely different scale. Within an indi-

text: different rooms are even more varied. The bathroom, for exam--
label: Paragraph

text: ple, makes far more elaborate specific demands than the living
label: Paragraph

text: room, but it is possible to take care of them in much less space.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus technically the prime architectural problem of distribution
label: Paragraph

text: is to adjust the irregular and unequal demands of function to reg-
label: Paragraph

text: ular construction and the use of standardized parts.
label: Paragraph

text: Just as the zesthetic principle of surface of volume has been
label: Paragraph

text: derived from the fact that architecture no longer has solid sup-
label: Paragraph

text: porting walls, the second principle, that of regularity, depends on
label: Paragraph

text: the regularity typical of the underlying skeleton of modern con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction. This second principle is expressed in an ordering of
label: Paragraph

text: design more consistent than would result merely from the
label: Paragraph

text: sesthetically unconscious use of regular structure and standard-
label: Paragraph

text: ized parts for varying and complicated functions. Thus the ex-
label: Paragraph

text: pression receives a visible regularity and consistency. This is the

label: Paragraph

text: ing are known rather than seen. (Pages 149 and 161.)

text: It must be remembered that the nearer approaches to absolute
label: Paragraph

text: regularity are also approaches to monotony, as the earlier refer-

text: ence to the loft building will have suggested. The principle of
label: Paragraph

text: regularity refers to a means of organization, a way of giving defi-
label: Paragraph

text: nite form to an architectural design, rather than to an end which
label: Paragraph

text: is sought for itself. As an end, regularity is modified by the equal
label: Paragraph

text: necessity, understood in all esthetic organization, of achieving a
label: Paragraph

text: proper degree of interest. What constitutes a proper degree of

text: interest is hardly to be determined in theory.

text: the confused vagaries of the intervening period, when the princi-

text: T.. development of modern city planning has brought an in-
label: Paragraph

text: creasing intervention of the political authorities in architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: In some cases the sesthetic effect of this intervention has. been for
label: Paragraph

text: the good, substituting harmony for anarchical diversity, as in the
label: Paragraph

text: buildings of Haussman’s day which line the Paris boulevards. In |
label: Paragraph

text: other cases it is unfortunate, as in the case of the New York zon-
label: Paragraph

text: ing law requiring the setback treatment of tall buildings; or in the
label: Paragraph

text: case of the Baupolizei (building-police) in German. cities, who
label: Paragraph

text: 1The German word, Siedlung, serves more convéniently and specifically to denominate: -
label: Paragraph

text: modem community housing projects than “garden suburb” or “residence subdivision.”
label: Paragraph

text: force later builders on a street to continue the steep roofs used on
label: Paragraph

text: the first houses.
label: Paragraph

text: But the state is more than a supervisor of architecture. It has
label: Paragraph

text: itself become a patron of architecture in fields previously left to
label: Paragraph

text: the individual. The state no longer erects only post-offices,
label: Paragraph

text: schools and administration buildings. All over Europe public
label: Caption

text: and semi-public agencies are concerning themselves with inex-
label: Paragraph

text: pensive housing. In America the patronage of housing develop-
label: Paragraph

text: ments by the state or by philanthropists, who so often carry on
label: Paragraph

text: activities which are left to the government abroad, is only begin-
label: Paragraph

text: ning.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the development of group planning along modern
label: Paragraph

text: lines in America the style of the individual houses in our “garden
label: Paragraph

text: suburbs” remains traditional. Eyen where modem construction
label: Paragraph

text: has been introduced, the sponsors have been loath to provide
label: Paragraph

text: moder design. Hence our Siedlungen are sometimes excellent
label: Paragraph

text: illustrations of sociological theory, but they are seldom examples
label: Paragraph

text: ef sound modern building and never works of architectural dis-
label: Paragraph

text: tinction. .
label: Paragraph

text: Yet even housing at minimal cost is potentially architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The individual minima! dwellings provide for a function so sim-.
label: Paragraph

text: ple and so little specialized that they are well within the realm of
label: Paragraph

text: building and quite capable of standardization. But a project de-
label: Paragraph

text: veloped as a whole constitutes a complex problem offering so
label: Paragraph

text: many opportunities for arbitrary choice that it may become archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture. American builders have standardized Tudor or Georgian
label: Paragraph

text: forms and have produced extremely bad architecture, as cheap
label: Paragraph

text: and meretricious as our modernistic skyscrapers. We may in the
label: Paragraph

text: future standardize more fully and more logically by following the
label: Paragraph

text: practice.of European architects.
label: Paragraph

text: In the better Siedlungen, cotirdination offers a breadth of pos-
label: Paragraph

text: sibilities such as the mere repetition of similar buildings cannot
label: Paragraph

text: give. The principle of regularity imposes a general order while
label: Paragraph

text: the provisions for the different private and public functions of a
label: Paragraph

text: complete Siedlung give variety and emphasis. The relation of the
label: Paragraph

text: repeated units of actual housing to the special units serving the
label: Paragraph

text: whole community is analogous to the relation in a hotel of the
label: Paragraph

text: single guest rooms to the public rooms.
label: Paragraph

text: Gratuitous cultivation of asymmetry in the Siedlung is an of-
label: Paragraph

text: fense against the principle of regularity. On the other hand, axial
label: Paragraph

text: symmetry will seldom be possible throughout because of the
label: Paragraph

text: necessities of proper orientation. (Page 158.) But the imposition
label: Paragraph

text: of the same esthetic disciplines on repeated units of housing and
label: Paragraph

text: on special buildings will naturally give consistency to the whole
label: Paragraph

text: composition.
label: Paragraph

text: Theatres, cafés, churches and schools will stand out. Because
label: Paragraph

text: of their greater scale it is possible to give them a more architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tural character than the ordinary surrounding buildings. Empha-
label: Paragraph

text: sized by the idiosyncrasies of their function, they symbolize
label: Paragraph

text: group activities. Because they break the particular system of reg-
label: Paragraph

text: ularity of the surrounding housing, they constitute points of cli-
label: Paragraph

text: mactic interest. (Page 224.)
label: Caption

text: The Siedlungen of the European functionalists generally
label: Paragraph

text: reach the neutral esthetic level of good building, while the work
label: Paragraph

text: of those who apply more consciously the disciplines of the con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporary style often rises to the level of architecture. The Sied-
label: Paragraph

text: lungen. of the latter are not less practical. We must not be misled
label: Paragraph

text: by the idealism of the European functionalists. Functionalism is
label: Paragraph

text: absolute as an idea rather than as a reality. As an idea it must
label: Paragraph

text: come to terms with other ideas such as that of zesthetic organiza~
label: Paragraph

text: tion.
label: Paragraph

text: The modern Siedlung raises the question of what is meant by.
label: Paragraph

text: function in architecture more pertinently than dees any other
label: Paragraph

text: type of building. The general function is clear both in Europe
label: Paragraph

text: and in America: to provide a large number of dwellings outside
label: Paragraph

text: the city but still not too distant from the place of work of the in-
label: Paragraph

text: habitants. Problems of communication, of retail merchandising
label: Paragraph

text: and of entertainment are various, but they offer no field for ar-
label: Paragraph

text: chitectural controversy. The more of such communal functions
label: Paragraph

text: that can be incorporated in the same general plan, the more in-
label: Paragraph

text: teresting and architectural will be the resultant Siedlung.
label: Paragraph

text: In the single residence units themselves the present and the
label: Paragraph

text: future come to grips. In the case of a house built for a definite
label: Paragraph

text: client and standing in its own grounds—still a very important
label: Paragraph

text: - architectural problem in every country of the world except
label: Paragraph

text: Russia—the functions of the house as a place to live in must be
label: Paragraph

text: worked out by the architect with the client. The man who is about
label: Paragraph

text: to build a house knows his needs or can be forced to discover
label: Paragraph

text: them by analysis. Indeed, satisfying the particular client is one
label: Paragraph

text: important function of architecture that the European functional-
label: Paragraph

text: ists usually avoid. For them such work is without sociological
label: Paragraph

text: significance.
label: Paragraph

text: The Siedlung implies preparation not for a given family but for
label: Paragraph

text: a typical family. This statistical monster, the typical family, has
label: Paragraph

text: no personal existence and cannot defend itself against the socio- |
label: Paragraph

text: logical theories of the architects. The European functionalists in
label: Paragraph

text: their annual conferences set up standards for ideal minimal
label: Paragraph

text: dwellings. These standards often have little relation to the actual
label: Paragraph

text: way of living of those who are to inhabit them. Yet such theoriz-
label: Paragraph

text: ing has value as an instrument of social progress. Architects in
label: Paragraph

text: private, as well as in public, practice must suggest and provide
label: Paragraph

text: for the amelioration and development of the functions of living.
label: Paragraph

text: They are specialists who can translate vague desires into reali-
label: Paragraph

text: ties. But there should be a balance between evolving ideal
label: Paragraph

text: houses for scientific living and providing comfortable houses for
label: Paragraph

text: Too often in European Siedlungen. the functionalists build for
label: Paragraph

text: some proletarian superman of the future. Yet in most buildings
label: Paragraph

text: the expressed desires of a given client are the most explicit and
label: Paragraph

text: difficult functions. Architects whose discipline is wsthetic as
label: Paragraph

text: well as functional are usually readier to provide what is actually
label: Paragraph

text: needed, Their idealism is satisfied by raising their Siedlungen. to
label: Paragraph

text: the level of architecture by effective general planning and dis-
label: Paragraph

text: tinctive composition. The idealism of the functionalists too often
label: Paragraph

text: demands that they provide what ought to be needed, even at the
label: Paragraph

text: expense of what is actually needed. Instead of facing the difficul-
label: Paragraph

text: ties of the present, they rush on to face the uncertain future.
label: Paragraph

text: There is a reverse side to this question of function in housing
label: Paragraph

text: projects. It is frequently demanded by local critics that ar-
label: Paragraph

text: chitects should cater to peculiar wants unknown in other commu-
label: Paragraph

text: nities. Windows arranged for strange forms of ventilation, or so
label: Paragraph

text: . subdivided that they may be opened without disarranging flower
label: Paragraph

text: pots on the sill, rooms catering to special methods of drying
label: Caption

text: clothes indoors, solid shutters on upper storeys to which no bur-
label: Paragraph

text: glar could climb, certainly are needless unless local traditions
label: Paragraph

text: insist upon them. In America, local traditions are further compli-
label: Paragraph

text: cated by an excessive sentimentality about the “homes” of the
label: Paragraph

text: past. |
label: Paragraph

text: The architect has a right to distinguish functions which are
label: Paragraph

text: major and general from those which are minor and local. In soci-
label: Paragraph

text: ological building he ought certainly to stress the universal at the
label: Paragraph

text: expense of the particular. He may even, for economic reasons
label: Paragraph

text: and for the sake of general architectural style, disregard entirely
label: Paragraph

text: the peculiarities of local tradition unless these are soundly based
label: Paragraph

text: on local weather conditions. His aim is to approach an ideal stan-
label: Paragraph

text: dard. But houses should not be functionally so advanced that
label: Paragraph

text: they are lived in under protest.
label: Paragraph

text: Whether the architects’ work be a single elaborate country
label: Paragraph

text: house, a public edifice, or a residence colony of apartments or
label: Paragraph

text: small dwellings, the application of esthetic principles of order,
label: Paragraph

text: the formal simplification of complexity, will raise a good work of
label: Paragraph

text: building to a fine monument of architecture. Whether the design
label: Paragraph

text: be for a single filling station or for a whole city quarter, quality of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural thought will count more than money spent on sites
label: Paragraph

text: or on fine materials. If there be a choice of site, if there be money
label: Paragraph

text: for chrome and marble, the beauty of natural surroundings. and
label: Paragraph

text: the beauty of rich smooth surfaces can only enhance the quality
label: Paragraph

text: . of architecture. An architecture, aristocratic rather than
label: Paragraph

text: puritanical, may rise sometimes on an Acropolis in all the luxury
label: Paragraph

text: of Pentelic marble and yet will grace with distinction the factory
label: Paragraph

text: and the Siedlung.
label: Paragraph

text: Buildings will continue to be looked at as well as used. It is
label: Paragraph

text: sutely one function of architecture to provide for sesthetic appre-
label: Paragraph

text: ciation, Fortunately the functionalists have riot altogether failed
label: Paragraph

text: to do so, Their achievements form an important part of the pro-
label: Paragraph

text: ductions of the international style.
label: Paragraph

text: Within this style there are no subsidiary manners which are
label: Paragraph

text: ecclesiastical or domestic or industrial. The symbolic expression |
label: Paragraph

text: of function by allusion to the past, which the half-modern ar-
label: Paragraph

text: chitects at the beginning of the century developed, has ceased to
label: Paragraph

text: be necessary. Where function is straightforwardly expressed, one
label: Paragraph

text: type of building will not be confounded with another. Nor need
label: Paragraph

text: that individuality break the premises of the style. The interna-
label: Paragraph

text: tional style is broad and elastic enough for many varying talents
label: Paragraph

text: and for many decades of development.
label: Paragraph

text: We have, as the Egyptians had or the Chinese, as the Greeks
label: Paragraph

text: and our own ancestors in the Middle Ages before us, a style
label: Paragraph

text: which orders the visible manifestation of a certain close relation-
label: Paragraph

text: ship between structure and function. Regardless of specific types
label: Paragraph

text: of structure or of function, the style has ‘a.definable seathetic.
label: Paragraph

text: That zsthetic, like modern technics, will develop and change; it
label: Paragraph

text: will hardly cease to exist. It is found in the humblest buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: as well as in monuments, fully architectural. Those. who have _
label: Paragraph

text: buried architecture, whether from a thwarted desire to continue
label: Paragraph

text: the past or from an over-anxiety te modify and hurry on the fu-
label: Paragraph

text: ture, have been premature: We have an architecture. still.
